Good concept and could be fun. I like the idea of having a mobile base.

But for f sake, the inventory management is abysmal.
- you start getting a ton of random items right from the start
- there is no sorting in inventory
- controls in inventory are confusing
- there is no pulling from chests when crafting. Like, WHAT? You already have the island thing that is your ship. So every block is connected anyway. There is no excuse to not have crafting from chests in a setup like this unless you just like torturing players with constantly having to takie things out of the chests. And of course chests are not that big! SO you have to have several of them very fast

The second problem is combat. Maybe it gets better later but at the beginning it felt really bad. I realized quickly that the best way to fight is just to whack the enemy as fast as possible and hope he dies before me. 
There is blocking, fine, but the enemies attack so fast you rarely have a window to attack after the block, because you will get hit anyway. And the block delay is weirdly high, like it takes 0.5-1s for the block to actually start blocking after the input.
I hear there is parrying but whatever I did, I couldn't trigger the parry lol. Not sure if the window for it is stupidly small or just at a weird time that it never actually happened for me.

Also starter weapons break stupidly fast, very annoying at the beginning when you are still figuring out what to do.

Anyway, I'm leaving a recommendation since I'm planning to check the game out after release. But if the problems mentioned above are not alleviated in some way I don't think I'll enjoy it.

I've played 14.7 hours, and defeated the Skeleton King.

Pros- 
Works fine on my ancient PC: running an A8 processor and a R9 380 graphics card. It should be unplayable, but it runs just fine. 
The premise: its fun, and it makes me want to know more.
The ship building (mobile island building): simple, intuitive, fun. You can be very creative, or you can min-max efficiency, or both. The island controls are very fun, its like flying a boat. You need to fuel engines, and turn some on and off to not waste fuel. Scavenging new parts is fun. You can completely  strip the ship down to its skeleton, which gives you a lot to work with.
-Exploration: This is great, it's a demo, so I don't expect a huge variance at this time. Iterating on what exists and adding more variance without changing the core elements would be suggested.
-Crafting: It's really great, the amount of blocks, recipes and gear is amazing for a demo. Hampered by poor inventory management
-Graphics: Good, I like the look, I like that the enemies blend in a bit to their surroundings. It keeps you from running around willy-nilly, and it makes them feel like they belong. Traps are nicely hidden, without being impossible to see.
-Progression: It's great. I don't mind that it take a long time to find a better weapon. I am happy that I found the bronze daggers recipe late, and completely changed my build at the 10 hour mark. I wasn't punished as weapons share perks. And I changed up my play style, which refreshed the gameplay.

-The AI this gets a honorary mention, as the AI has a lot of potential.

The meh-
The combat: It's fine, it needs work. Bronze Daggers with doom rune, and the game is a piece of cake. Combat is like oblivion, and you spam attacks. Parrying and interrupting attacks doesn't seem to work, so trying to get good (like kingdom come, deliverance) is not really feasible. I'm fine if it stays the way it is, but it's not great. The system to make it better is already in the game, it just needs to be fully realised.

The bad-
Inventory management is terrible. Play Necesse to see it done well. This has no crafting from chests, no stackable crafting without spam clicking one at a time. no lockable inventory items, no sorting.

Archery: it doesn't get damage bonuses from perks. Head shot to stun perk should be a one and done, not a percentage increase that doesn't really benefit the player as it maxes below 50. A wood bow is useless unless unless you cheese it with barriers.

The AI- It gets stuck or spawns in walls frequently. AI cant destroy blocks (just barriers, or player placed blocks would be nice) to try and get to you. You can cheese AI easily. AI doesn't work together, which is fine for low level skeletons, but advanced skeletons should change the behaviour of other skeletons, making advanced enemies priority targets.
You can kite enemies into the water or off islands and kill them. Kind of cool, as they are skeletons, and dumb. However it seems broken.

Other things are bad, but they are works in progress (eg. changing keybindings is not possible) so I wont mention them.

Absolutely play this demo, You will have fun.

The game is fun, open world, has a lot of adventure to it, but it has a LOT of issues and the demo felt more like I was given a product to QA not a fully developed game with limited content. The game is either taking advantage of the Hytale cancellation, or just very conveniently released.
Now onto the issues they need to fix/address.

[h2]Menu Shenanigans:[/h2]
- Can't shift click back into your hotbar like you can into your inventory FROM the hotbar
- Pressing 1-9 while looking at items in inventory/storage does not swap places or assign them to your hotbar
- Crafting Recipes/Benches don't take materials from nearby chests (extremely popular in survival RPGs like Nightingale)
- No shift clicking recipes/adjustable slider to make multiple crafts, had to manually click Roasted Beef 80 times

[h2]Combat/Movement Shenanigans:[/h2]
- Sprint speed is almost imperceptibly faster. Needs to be noticeably faster
- Combat feels too much like a slap fight. You can't mitigate damage and are forced to rely on armor + healing items (details below on what I mean)
- Parry mechanic is awful and contributes to ^ because you must parry with exact timing [b]AND IT'S DELAYED!!![/b] Cannot instant parry the way you can in BOTW, and you cannot let it linger either. The animation leading up to the actual parry leaves you vulnerable to getting hit.
- Skeleton attack speed is too fast, can't parry light hits on reaction since the parry is so delayed, contributing to ^ and making the attrition-feeling combat feel like an inevitable chore, not a skillful challenge.
- Healing sucks and doesn't scale with max health. Going through each skeleton battle ends with you eating 5 steaks and waiting 30 seconds for each one to finish, making each fight a chore after the fact because you KNOW you're going to get hit a lot, and you KNOW you're going to have to spend 4 minutes after every scuffle to heal back to full. 
- Let us stack healing effects from foods or potions!
- Arrow velocity is too slow and not realistic. A fletched arrow flies slower than an IRL rock from a slingshot
- Cannot retrieve arrows shot into terrain in ANY capacity
- Weapon durability is hot garbage. They deplete way too fast.
- Crouching does not always prevent falling off a ledge
- Can't crouch midair/maintain crouching. Going down stairs messes with this.
- Holding jump keeps jumping (good thing) but stops if you, at any point in time, bump your head (bad)

[h2]Cooking/Recipe Shenanigans:[/h2]
- Limited cooking recipes, can't just grill mushrooms or make berry jam even though they are clearly safe to eat
- Can't collect rainwater in barrels for crops 
- Crops don't automatically get watered when it's raining
- No tooltips on what is wrong with your crops (altitude or soil)
- No buckets to collect ground water either
- No way to tell if you know a recipe or not, have to remember or manually check each one when you come across them

[h2]Building Shenanigans:[/h2]
- The half slabs, 3/4 slabs, and 1/4 slabs all have weird placement logic. Placing them feels less consistent and intuitive than in Minecraft.
- Tiny window of opportunity for placing blocks under you if you're jumping in place. Wish you could hold RMB and hold spacebar and it would just place blocks as soon as possible.
- Annoying that ALL blocks even the ones you craft revert back to stones/planks when you break them, custom or not. Because of this you cannot harvest pretty blocks from dungeons, and redoing builds or changing your ship is an absolute CHORE. This game actively deincentivizes me to build anything personal because of how much of a headache it will be.
- Crafted building blocks cannot be changed from one form to another. Allow me to change my mind from chiseled, to blocky, to smooth variants back and forth!
- No ladders or rope ladders to climb. I don't want to jump 50 feet onto an island and take fall damage every time

[h2]Settings/Accessibility/Miscellaneous Shenanigans:[/h2]
- Not being able to rebind any keys
- No toggle sprint or toggle crouch in settings
- The "I" button on Keyboard opens and closes inventory, but not in storages. Every time you open a dresser or chest you have to press ESC to exit the inventory
- No quick stack option or ability to sort to nearby chests
- Weird FPS drops in certain locations, or while holding certain items
- Islands are tiny, there's no incentive to make a "home base" anywhere and lay down roots. You are doomed to be a murder hobo forever

[h3]Final thoughts[/h3]
Game has a great foundation and seems like it would be really fun, but there's so much missing polish. Needs a LOT of changes and fixes before I would consider buying it.

Everwind's Demo shows a lot of promise in different areas.

The premise seems really solid. Voxel sandbox RPG where you fly around on an airship that you constantly are building and expanding to your liking to find more loot, upgrades for yourself, resources, what have you. 
The QOL of the Compass is also something I feel is very fitting for the game and something I enjoyed greatly. Being able to teleport to the ship at any moment, especially in Multiplayer, really saves hassle and time to leave places. I like the spyglass as well to see islands you've already explored and which ones are worth checking out or not in the first place.

There are things that very obviously need work, like the Combat feeling fairly one-dimensional and almost like Oblivion / Skyrim, but a bit lacking. The foundation of regular swings, charged swing to break guards, and guarding for Melee combat would be fine if it were not for the speed at which enemies swing or how slow they react to your tactics. It seems at the moment the best solution is to just swing wildly with your stamina to kill anything before it can meaningfully damaage you.
Magic and Ranged are similarly simple, since it's mostly a point and click ranged projectile from what I could tell of what I messed around with.

Bugs are to be expected, especially for a demo, and extra so for a demo of a voxel-based sandbox with moving structures that have collision. But they were definitely all around the place. I'm sure a lot of them will be hammered out, especially since I was playing in Multiiplayer with 3 other friends. 

I think a major thing for me right now is the feel of interacting with certain systems. To name a few:
-Inventory Management and Usage
-Not being able to use a crafting station or chest if a friend is already doing so, this requires you to wait or make multiple if you want to get around the inconvenience of this
-The sea level is persistant through blocks, meaning that if you dig down on the surface of an island (say, to look for ore for Copper) you'll hit water. You can't dive, as the game sends you straight to the top of water, and it just generally feels confusing why its persistent everywhere through blocks. 

With time I'm sure there will be clarity, but for now on the first thing I'd like to suggest just a few small things that might make inventory stuff feel nicer:
- Pressing 1-0 on your keyboard while mousing over an item in your inventory places it in that hotbar slot. This is common in a lot of games like this, and feels really good for fast management of getting things where you can immediately use them.
- Shift Clicking things in your hotbar into the upper inventory, and vice versa. 
- A way to craft an item multiple times instead of clicking the craft button each time. A selectable amount (min-max, number to craft in general) would be nice.

At its core it's a Minecraft clone that goes in its own direction. The main premise is that the world itself is a series of islands, some at sea level and others floating in the sky, which the player can explore using a flyable ship they can build, discovering dungeons to delve into as well as gathering much needed resources such as copper ore found in veins scattered about the various islands. 

The ship mechanic I found fantastic as the player is able, block by block, to construct their very own ship to their personal design, limited only by the upgradeable engines they've crafted which determine how large and heavy the ship can be. Currently the ships contain a special block called 'Ancient Metal' which I couldn't figure out how to destroy, but these blocks basically act as the skeleton of the ship allowing you to construct the body. 

If you're going to try this game out for yourself, do not forget to use your compass! You can use it to instantly teleport back to your ship and should you ever lose said ship, the compass will direct you to its location. Also, pick up sticks and stones lying around to craft a stone axe then chop down plenty of trees, you can use the logs as fuel for the ships engines. 

My only two major qualms with the game as it is right now is combat and building. Placing blocks is a little clunky and doesn't feel smooth, specially compared to other similar titles such as Enshrouded. I found myself having to move around a lot more and get into a specific position at times to place blocks, something that I rarely have to do in other sandbox titles. 

Finally the combat is very basic and somewhat arcadeish. I think it would be much better to improve the combat animations via choreographed attacks and maybe a timed blocking system wherein you need to block at a specific moment in order to avoid damage. Currently the best combat method is to spam click to kill something and this isn't really fun compared to what I know the developers could cook up.

Ultimately in two hours I managed to upgrade the engines enough to reach the main island featured in the demo and kill the skeleton boss, after which there wasn't  really anything else to do. What was available was incredibly fun and I can't wait for the full release, Minecraft and dungeon delving... What isn't to love?

I've played 14.7 hours, and defeated the Skeleton King.

Pros- 
Works fine on my ancient PC: running an A8 processor and a R9 380 graphics card. It should be unplayable, but it runs just fine. 
The premise: its fun, and it makes me want to know more.
The ship building (mobile island building): simple, intuitive, fun. You can be very creative, or you can min-max efficiency, or both. The island controls are very fun, its like flying a boat. You need to fuel engines, and turn some on and off to not waste fuel. Scavenging new parts is fun. You can completely  strip the ship down to its skeleton, which gives you a lot to work with.
-Exploration: This is great, it's a demo, so I don't expect a huge variance at this time. Iterating on what exists and adding more variance without changing the core elements would be suggested.
-Crafting: It's really great, the amount of blocks, recipes and gear is amazing for a demo. Hampered by poor inventory management
-Graphics: Good, I like the look, I like that the enemies blend in a bit to their surroundings. It keeps you from running around willy-nilly, and it makes them feel like they belong. Traps are nicely hidden, without being impossible to see.
-Progression: It's great. I don't mind that it take a long time to find a better weapon. I am happy that I found the bronze daggers recipe late, and completely changed my build at the 10 hour mark. I wasn't punished as weapons share perks. And I changed up my play style, which refreshed the gameplay.

-The AI this gets a honorary mention, as the AI has a lot of potential.

The meh-
The combat: It's fine, it needs work. Bronze Daggers with doom rune, and the game is a piece of cake. Combat is like oblivion, and you spam attacks. Parrying and interrupting attacks doesn't seem to work, so trying to get good (like kingdom come, deliverance) is not really feasible. I'm fine if it stays the way it is, but it's not great. The system to make it better is already in the game, it just needs to be fully realised.

The bad-
Inventory management is terrible. Play Necesse to see it done well. This has no crafting from chests, no stackable crafting without spam clicking one at a time. no lockable inventory items, no sorting.

Archery: it doesn't get damage bonuses from perks. Head shot to stun perk should be a one and done, not a percentage increase that doesn't really benefit the player as it maxes below 50. A wood bow is useless unless unless you cheese it with barriers.

The AI- It gets stuck or spawns in walls frequently. AI cant destroy blocks (just barriers, or player placed blocks would be nice) to try and get to you. You can cheese AI easily. AI doesn't work together, which is fine for low level skeletons, but advanced skeletons should change the behaviour of other skeletons, making advanced enemies priority targets.
You can kite enemies into the water or off islands and kill them. Kind of cool, as they are skeletons, and dumb. However it seems broken.

Other things are bad, but they are works in progress (eg. changing keybindings is not possible) so I wont mention them.

Absolutely play this demo, You will have fun.

Now onto the issues they need to fix/address.

[h2]Menu Shenanigans:[/h2]
- Can't shift click back into your hotbar like you can into your inventory FROM the hotbar
- Pressing 1-9 while looking at items in inventory/storage does not swap places or assign them to your hotbar
- Crafting Recipes/Benches don't take materials from nearby chests (extremely popular in survival RPGs like Nightingale)
- No shift clicking recipes/adjustable slider to make multiple crafts, had to manually click Roasted Beef 80 times

[h2]Combat/Movement Shenanigans:[/h2]
- Sprint speed is almost imperceptibly faster. Needs to be noticeably faster
- Combat feels too much like a slap fight. You can't mitigate damage and are forced to rely on armor + healing items (details below on what I mean)
- Parry mechanic is awful and contributes to ^ because you must parry with exact timing [b]AND IT'S DELAYED!!![/b] Cannot instant parry the way you can in BOTW, and you cannot let it linger either. The animation leading up to the actual parry leaves you vulnerable to getting hit.
- Skeleton attack speed is too fast, can't parry light hits on reaction since the parry is so delayed, contributing to ^ and making the attrition-feeling combat feel like an inevitable chore, not a skillful challenge.
- Healing sucks and doesn't scale with max health. Going through each skeleton battle ends with you eating 5 steaks and waiting 30 seconds for each one to finish, making each fight a chore after the fact because you KNOW you're going to get hit a lot, and you KNOW you're going to have to spend 4 minutes after every scuffle to heal back to full. 
- Let us stack healing effects from foods or potions!
- Arrow velocity is too slow and not realistic. A fletched arrow flies slower than an IRL rock from a slingshot
- Cannot retrieve arrows shot into terrain in ANY capacity
- Weapon durability is hot garbage. They deplete way too fast.
- Crouching does not always prevent falling off a ledge
- Can't crouch midair/maintain crouching. Going down stairs messes with this.
- Holding jump keeps jumping (good thing) but stops if you, at any point in time, bump your head (bad)

[h2]Cooking/Recipe Shenanigans:[/h2]
- Limited cooking recipes, can't just grill mushrooms or make berry jam even though they are clearly safe to eat
- Can't collect rainwater in barrels for crops 
- Crops don't automatically get watered when it's raining
- No tooltips on what is wrong with your crops (altitude or soil)
- No buckets to collect ground water either
- No way to tell if you know a recipe or not, have to remember or manually check each one when you come across them

[h2]Building Shenanigans:[/h2]
- The half slabs, 3/4 slabs, and 1/4 slabs all have weird placement logic. Placing them feels less consistent and intuitive than in Minecraft.
- Tiny window of opportunity for placing blocks under you if you're jumping in place. Wish you could hold RMB and hold spacebar and it would just place blocks as soon as possible.
- Annoying that ALL blocks even the ones you craft revert back to stones/planks when you break them, custom or not. Because of this you cannot harvest pretty blocks from dungeons, and redoing builds or changing your ship is an absolute CHORE. This game actively deincentivizes me to build anything personal because of how much of a headache it will be.
- Crafted building blocks cannot be changed from one form to another. Allow me to change my mind from chiseled, to blocky, to smooth variants back and forth!
- No ladders or rope ladders to climb. I don't want to jump 50 feet onto an island and take fall damage every time

[h2]Settings/Accessibility/Miscellaneous Shenanigans:[/h2]
- Not being able to rebind any keys
- No toggle sprint or toggle crouch in settings
- The "I" button on Keyboard opens and closes inventory, but not in storages. Every time you open a dresser or chest you have to press ESC to exit the inventory
- No quick stack option or ability to sort to nearby chests
- Weird FPS drops in certain locations, or while holding certain items
- Islands are tiny, there's no incentive to make a "home base" anywhere and lay down roots. You are doomed to be a murder hobo forever

Currently, what sets Everwind apart from any other block game? The answer should be the game's [i]Unique Selling Point[/i], the airship gameplay and exploration. However, at least in the demo, all features feel seriously underbaked and underwhelming. I would not be surprised if Minecraft mods have achieved a similar level of gameplay despite the game's engine barely supporting such functionality.

Exploration is at least better than in a few other action-adventurey-RPGish games I have played. I was pleasantly surprised to find improved gear, or even weapons and armor that are above what I can make myself from various chests. It is nice to see that the game is not above rewarding the player for exploration. In addition, the verticality in dungeons is a very pleasant addition.

However, that is where the praise ends for now. Below are a myriad of smaller and larger issues that cropped up during the demo gameplay.

[h3]Combat issues:[/h3]
[list]
[*]Combat is functional, but too simplistic. You have a basic attack, a heavy attack and a block. Heavy attacks are only useful as openers or if the enemy has a lot of armor. Blocking... might work? Not sure. Beyond that you just swing until the enemy stops moving. Most of them don't have the DPS to kill you before you kill them, anyway.
[*]Different weapons do not feel particularly different at all. That said, I only saw a couple of different kinds of weapons, but they were largely similar. Why does nobody try to copy Vermintide's homework?
[*]Enemies are only threatening in large numbers, or only if you have for some reason run out of food to heal yourself with. Most enemies, including the Skeleton King are easily defeated by standing on top of something they cannot reach.
[/list]

[h3]Survival issues:[/h3]
[list]
[*]Survival effectively does not exist. You do not have needs other than keeping your health above 0. You can only lose health through falling from extreme heights, being hit by traps or through combat.
[*]Food is plentiful and its only purpose is to serve as glorified healing potions.
[*]Alchemy is pointless and not particularly fun. You have to match three ingredients with matching effects to make a basic potion that is likely not even particularly useful. You cannot see more than one out of three possible effects in the demo.
[*]Repairing items is laughably easy. Copper is the most abundant metal in the game, and all you need are a few pieces of ore to to turn into ingots, and some planks to make a repair kit that fixes anything to maximum durability.
[*]The game is severely hindered by everything being gated behind recipes you find randomly. Up to and including smelting ingots, and making anything out of said ingots. You can easily get into a situation where you find recipes for bronze or iron equipment, but can't smelt the ingots to make said items.
[*]Recipes are not shared. In multiplayer means one player may be able to smelt ingots, but another might have a recipe for the tools or weapons that utilize those ingots. Given random generation of recipes, you may wind up with heaps of duplicates but not the ones you need.
[/list]

[h3]Airship issues:[/h3]
[list]
[*]The airship building is completely arbitrary. Right now the most effective way to build your flying boat is to just make a one-dimensional flying saucer. Form and function are completely divorced from one another.
[*]Airship components are arbitrary. The balloons effectively do nothing beyond add +250 max height, limited by the level of your ship's core. You do not have to balance the lift evenly around your boat. Even without any balloons, your boat can still hover up to 15 blocks (technically 7, because sea level is 7 blocks). 
[*]I'm not sure if the generators do anything at all beyond just toggling your balloons and rotors on for as long as there is power. Do you need more than one? Who knows.
[*]Furthermore, the motors that add speed to your boat can be placed anywhere, even in places where their air currents should be completely blocked. In addition, given that in the demo the max speed is 13.5 blocks, you need two propellers to get to 13 max speed. The third motor adds only a .5 block speed increase before limited by the hard cap.
[*]Mass does not exist. Your airship can carry as much stuff on it as you can fit in boxes and whatnot. You do not need to build a base anywhere, because your flying saucer does and carries everything.
[*]Your airship seemingly can not take damage, making using different blocks entirely cosmetic. The most effective way to make your airboat, therefore, is to make a flat saucer with the ballons and motors stacked next to one another in some corner, fed by a single generator.
[*]If the airboat cannot take damage, then there likely are no flying enemies either that could threaten you and your boat, making using harder blocks pointless and the flying itself uneventful and boring.
[/list]

[h3]Technical issues:[/h3]
[list]
[*]The game freezes consistently after a few hours of gameplay.
[*]Turning up the chunk loading setting causes crippling chugging.
[*]The game lags considerably when an island is generated.
[*]Virtually no quality of life features. Cannot easily stack stuff in boxes, have to do everything manually and one by one. Same for crafting, no way to craft large amounts of items at once.
[*]No FOV settings?
[*]No rebindable keys in demo?
[/list]

Hopefully the full game will provide a far better air boat captain/crew fantasy than what the demo showcased. The systems need more depth and design. The airship should be the most developed feature and the beating heart and soul of the game. Yet, as it stands right now, it seems little more than a cute gimmick for the game to set itself apart from any other block game.

Without a road map, I can't say for certain that the game is going in the right direction. It has HUGE promise considering the mechanics and little details that already exist so far for this demo.

I'm certain the ships being provided from the start is for the demo ONLY to give players a quick cut to the airship gameplay, however if they're handed out like this in the final product, the main selling point of this game (for me and likely many others) will feel pretty shallow. I highly doubt this is the case, but if it is, then it's pretty sad.

I think it's fine if there's far and few wrecked ships for you to salvage or convert into a fully working airship, but starting from the ground up would be awesome as well. Progression in this game is going to be a major make or break point for me, and if it's as shallow as the demo experience is providing, I'm going to get really bored of this faster than I do with my Minecraft phases. So what are my personal takes/expectations? This isn't going to be fully organized, just some key points from the few hours I've played.

- A slow but meaningful journey to building your first airship.

- Combat improvements (Saw complaints about poorly telegraphed attacks and how it's basically a slapping contest for who slaps the fastest, I strongly agree with this comparison. Combat is pretty dull currently.)

- Enemy variety. If all of the enemies have to be skeletons, that's fine, but I would like to see the skeletons be something more than melee and ranged fighters. (They use mounts or other creatures for whatever evil things they do for example.) This could incentivize the use of multiple combat approaches, and maybe inspire the improved combat?

- Using the separate crafting benches feels a bit arbitrary if you are able to craft a majority of things like the different wood blocks in your characters inventory. Though I can kinda see where they're going with them since certain benches can craft specific things.

- Exploration is a bit iffy to me. I'd love to be able to claim an island as a home base that I can park my ship at when I return from exploring. The problem is that there's no way to mark or indicate your home base without building some obvious structure on the island you settle on. I was hoping for more of a hud element that I can bring into view with the compass, unless there's something I missed?

- Mid to end game should definitely captialize on the airship aspect of the game. There was one island I saw floating high above my ships limit and noticed some dungeon structure tucked into the sides. Plenty of open space to park directly into the dungeon in a way which provides a really neat approach to the dungeons. Though I feel the higher a player goes, the harder the game should get? I'm not entirely certain on how this should work, but if the loot you get doesn't scale with your progression, we're gonna end up with a Minecraft failure where you're essentially giving the player a stack of diamonds before they can even craft a wooden pickaxe.

Is there anything I missed? I'm deeply invested in seeing where this game goes. For now, I'll leave it as a negative review since I'm concerned about progression and the mid to end game experience. Overall, I'm very excited for this title. Compared to Minecraft, this one has a specific focus in mind.

Currently, what sets Everwind apart from any other block game? The answer should be the game's [i]Unique Selling Point[/i], the airship gameplay and exploration. However, at least in the demo, all features feel seriously underbaked and underwhelming. I would not be surprised if Minecraft mods have achieved a similar level of gameplay despite the game's engine barely supporting such functionality.

Exploration is at least better than in a few other action-adventurey-RPGish games I have played. I was pleasantly surprised to find improved gear, or even weapons and armor that are above what I can make myself from various chests. It is nice to see that the game is not above rewarding the player for exploration. In addition, the verticality in dungeons is a very pleasant addition.

However, that is where the praise ends for now. Below are a myriad of smaller and larger issues that cropped up during the demo gameplay.

[h3]Combat issues:[/h3]
[list]
[*]Combat is functional, but too simplistic. You have a basic attack, a heavy attack and a block. Heavy attacks are only useful as openers or if the enemy has a lot of armor. Blocking... might work? Not sure. Beyond that you just swing until the enemy stops moving. Most of them don't have the DPS to kill you before you kill them, anyway.
[*]Different weapons do not feel particularly different at all. That said, I only saw a couple of different kinds of weapons, but they were largely similar. Why does nobody try to copy Vermintide's homework?
[*]Enemies are only threatening in large numbers, or only if you have for some reason run out of food to heal yourself with. Most enemies, including the Skeleton King are easily defeated by standing on top of something they cannot reach.
[/list]

[h3]Survival issues:[/h3]
[list]
[*]Survival effectively does not exist. You do not have needs other than keeping your health above 0. You can only lose health through falling from extreme heights, being hit by traps or through combat.
[*]Food is plentiful and its only purpose is to serve as glorified healing potions.
[*]Alchemy is pointless and not particularly fun. You have to match three ingredients with matching effects to make a basic potion that is likely not even particularly useful. You cannot see more than one out of three possible effects in the demo.
[*]Repairing items is laughably easy. Copper is the most abundant metal in the game, and all you need are a few pieces of ore to to turn into ingots, and some planks to make a repair kit that fixes anything to maximum durability.
[*]The game is severely hindered by everything being gated behind recipes you find randomly. Up to and including smelting ingots, and making anything out of said ingots. You can easily get into a situation where you find recipes for bronze or iron equipment, but can't smelt the ingots to make said items.
[*]Recipes are not shared. In multiplayer means one player may be able to smelt ingots, but another might have a recipe for the tools or weapons that utilize those ingots. Given random generation of recipes, you may wind up with heaps of duplicates but not the ones you need.
[/list]

[h3]Airship issues:[/h3]
[list]
[*]The airship building is completely arbitrary. Right now the most effective way to build your flying boat is to just make a one-dimensional flying saucer. Form and function are completely divorced from one another.
[*]Airship components are arbitrary. The balloons effectively do nothing beyond add +250 max height, limited by the level of your ship's core. You do not have to balance the lift evenly around your boat. Even without any balloons, your boat can still hover up to 15 blocks (technically 7, because sea level is 7 blocks). 
[*]I'm not sure if the generators do anything at all beyond just toggling your balloons and rotors on for as long as there is power. Do you need more than one? Who knows.
[*]Furthermore, the motors that add speed to your boat can be placed anywhere, even in places where their air currents should be completely blocked. In addition, given that in the demo the max speed is 13.5 blocks, you need two propellers to get to 13 max speed. The third motor adds only a .5 block speed increase before limited by the hard cap.
[*]Mass does not exist. Your airship can carry as much stuff on it as you can fit in boxes and whatnot. You do not need to build a base anywhere, because your flying saucer does and carries everything.
[*]Your airship seemingly can not take damage, making using different blocks entirely cosmetic. The most effective way to make your airboat, therefore, is to make a flat saucer with the ballons and motors stacked next to one another in some corner, fed by a single generator.
[*]If the airboat cannot take damage, then there likely are no flying enemies either that could threaten you and your boat, making using harder blocks pointless and the flying itself uneventful and boring.
[/list]

[h3]Technical issues:[/h3]
[list]
[*]The game freezes consistently after a few hours of gameplay.
[*]Turning up the chunk loading setting causes crippling chugging.
[*]The game lags considerably when an island is generated.
[*]Virtually no quality of life features. Cannot easily stack stuff in boxes, have to do everything manually and one by one. Same for crafting, no way to craft large amounts of items at once.
[*]No FOV settings?
[*]No rebindable keys in demo?
[/list]

Hopefully the full game will provide a far better air boat captain/crew fantasy than what the demo showcased. The systems need more depth and design. The airship should be the most developed feature and the beating heart and soul of the game. Yet, as it stands right now, it seems little more than a cute gimmick for the game to set itself apart from any other block game.

Without a road map, I can't say for certain that the game is going in the right direction. It has HUGE promise considering the mechanics and little details that already exist so far for this demo.

I'm certain the ships being provided from the start is for the demo ONLY to give players a quick cut to the airship gameplay, however if they're handed out like this in the final product, the main selling point of this game (for me and likely many others) will feel pretty shallow. I highly doubt this is the case, but if it is, then it's pretty sad.

I think it's fine if there's far and few wrecked ships for you to salvage or convert into a fully working airship, but starting from the ground up would be awesome as well. Progression in this game is going to be a major make or break point for me, and if it's as shallow as the demo experience is providing, I'm going to get really bored of this faster than I do with my Minecraft phases. So what are my personal takes/expectations? This isn't going to be fully organized, just some key points from the few hours I've played.

- A slow but meaningful journey to building your first airship.

- Combat improvements (Saw complaints about poorly telegraphed attacks and how it's basically a slapping contest for who slaps the fastest, I strongly agree with this comparison. Combat is pretty dull currently.)

- Enemy variety. If all of the enemies have to be skeletons, that's fine, but I would like to see the skeletons be something more than melee and ranged fighters. (They use mounts or other creatures for whatever evil things they do for example.) This could incentivize the use of multiple combat approaches, and maybe inspire the improved combat?

- Using the separate crafting benches feels a bit arbitrary if you are able to craft a majority of things like the different wood blocks in your characters inventory. Though I can kinda see where they're going with them since certain benches can craft specific things.

- Exploration is a bit iffy to me. I'd love to be able to claim an island as a home base that I can park my ship at when I return from exploring. The problem is that there's no way to mark or indicate your home base without building some obvious structure on the island you settle on. I was hoping for more of a hud element that I can bring into view with the compass, unless there's something I missed?

There was one island I saw floating high above my ships limit and noticed some dungeon structure tucked into the sides. Plenty of open space to park directly into the dungeon in a way which provides a really neat approach to the dungeons. Though I feel the higher a player goes, the harder the game should get? I'm not entirely certain on how this should work, but if the loot you get doesn't scale with your progression, we're gonna end up with a Minecraft failure where you're essentially giving the player a stack of diamonds before they can even craft a wooden pickaxe.

Is there anything I missed? I'm deeply invested in seeing where this game goes. For now, I'll leave it as a negative review since I'm concerned about progression and the mid to end game experience. Overall, I'm very excited for this title. Compared to Minecraft, this one has a specific focus in mind.

Currently, what sets Everwind apart from any other block game? The answer should be the game's [i]Unique Selling Point[/i], the airship gameplay and exploration. However, at least in the demo, all features feel seriously underbaked and underwhelming. I would not be surprised if Minecraft mods have achieved a similar level of gameplay despite the game's engine barely supporting such functionality.

Exploration is at least better than in a few other action-adventurey-RPGish games I have played. I was pleasantly surprised to find improved gear, or even weapons and armor that are above what I can make myself from various chests. It is nice to see that the game is not above rewarding the player for exploration. In addition, the verticality in dungeons is a very pleasant addition.

However, that is where the praise ends for now. Below are a myriad of smaller and larger issues that cropped up during the demo gameplay.

[h3]Combat issues:[/h3]
[list]
[*]Combat is functional, but too simplistic. You have a basic attack, a heavy attack and a block. Heavy attacks are only useful as openers or if the enemy has a lot of armor. Blocking... might work? Not sure. Beyond that you just swing until the enemy stops moving. Most of them don't have the DPS to kill you before you kill them, anyway.
[*]Different weapons do not feel particularly different at all. That said, I only saw a couple of different kinds of weapons, but they were largely similar. Why does nobody try to copy Vermintide's homework?
[*]Enemies are only threatening in large numbers, or only if you have for some reason run out of food to heal yourself with. Most enemies, including the Skeleton King are easily defeated by standing on top of something they cannot reach.
[/list]

[h3]Survival issues:[/h3]
[list]
[*]Survival effectively does not exist. You do not have needs other than keeping your health above 0. You can only lose health through falling from extreme heights, being hit by traps or through combat.
[*]Food is plentiful and its only purpose is to serve as glorified healing potions.
[*]Alchemy is pointless and not particularly fun. You have to match three ingredients with matching effects to make a basic potion that is likely not even particularly useful. You cannot see more than one out of three possible effects in the demo.
[*]Repairing items is laughably easy. Copper is the most abundant metal in the game, and all you need are a few pieces of ore to to turn into ingots, and some planks to make a repair kit that fixes anything to maximum durability.
[*]The game is severely hindered by everything being gated behind recipes you find randomly. Up to and including smelting ingots, and making anything out of said ingots. You can easily get into a situation where you find recipes for bronze or iron equipment, but can't smelt the ingots to make said items.
[*]Recipes are not shared. In multiplayer means one player may be able to smelt ingots, but another might have a recipe for the tools or weapons that utilize those ingots. Given random generation of recipes, you may wind up with heaps of duplicates but not the ones you need.
[/list]

[h3]Airship issues:[/h3]
[list]
[*]The airship building is completely arbitrary. Right now the most effective way to build your flying boat is to just make a one-dimensional flying saucer. Form and function are completely divorced from one another.
[*]Airship components are arbitrary. The balloons effectively do nothing beyond add +250 max height, limited by the level of your ship's core. You do not have to balance the lift evenly around your boat. Even without any balloons, your boat can still hover up to 15 blocks (technically 7, because sea level is 7 blocks). 
[*]I'm not sure if the generators do anything at all beyond just toggling your balloons and rotors on for as long as there is power. Do you need more than one? Who knows.
[*]Furthermore, the motors that add speed to your boat can be placed anywhere, even in places where their air currents should be completely blocked. In addition, given that in the demo the max speed is 13.5 blocks, you need two propellers to get to 13 max speed. The third motor adds only a .5 block speed increase before limited by the hard cap.
[*]Mass does not exist. Your airship can carry as much stuff on it as you can fit in boxes and whatnot. You do not need to build a base anywhere, because your flying saucer does and carries everything.
[*]Your airship seemingly can not take damage, making using different blocks entirely cosmetic. The most effective way to make your airboat, therefore, is to make a flat saucer with the ballons and motors stacked next to one another in some corner, fed by a single generator.
[*]If the airboat cannot take damage, then there likely are no flying enemies either that could threaten you and your boat, making using harder blocks pointless and the flying itself uneventful and boring.
[/list]

[h3]Technical issues:[/h3]
[list]
[*]The game freezes consistently after a few hours of gameplay.
[*]Turning up the chunk loading setting causes crippling chugging.
[*]The game lags considerably when an island is generated.
[*]Virtually no quality of life features. Cannot easily stack stuff in boxes, have to do everything manually and one by one. Same for crafting, no way to craft large amounts of items at once.
[*]No FOV settings?
[*]No rebindable keys in demo?
[/list]

Hopefully the full game will provide a far better air boat captain/crew fantasy than what the demo showcased. The systems need more depth and design. The airship should be the most developed feature and the beating heart and soul of the game. Yet, as it stands right now, it seems little more than a cute gimmick for the game to set itself apart from any other block game.

Without a road map, I can't say for certain that the game is going in the right direction. It has HUGE promise considering the mechanics and little details that already exist so far for this demo.

I'm certain the ships being provided from the start is for the demo ONLY to give players a quick cut to the airship gameplay, however if they're handed out like this in the final product, the main selling point of this game (for me and likely many others) will feel pretty shallow. I highly doubt this is the case, but if it is, then it's pretty sad.

I think it's fine if there's far and few wrecked ships for you to salvage or convert into a fully working airship, but starting from the ground up would be awesome as well. Progression in this game is going to be a major make or break point for me, and if it's as shallow as the demo experience is providing, I'm going to get really bored of this faster than I do with my Minecraft phases. So what are my personal takes/expectations? This isn't going to be fully organized, just some key points from the few hours I've played.

- A slow but meaningful journey to building your first airship.

- Combat improvements (Saw complaints about poorly telegraphed attacks and how it's basically a slapping contest for who slaps the fastest, I strongly agree with this comparison. Combat is pretty dull currently.)

- Enemy variety. If all of the enemies have to be skeletons, that's fine, but I would like to see the skeletons be something more than melee and ranged fighters. (They use mounts or other creatures for whatever evil things they do for example.) This could incentivize the use of multiple combat approaches, and maybe inspire the improved combat?

- Using the separate crafting benches feels a bit arbitrary if you are able to craft a majority of things like the different wood blocks in your characters inventory. Though I can kinda see where they're going with them since certain benches can craft specific things.

- Exploration is a bit iffy to me. I'd love to be able to claim an island as a home base that I can park my ship at when I return from exploring. The problem is that there's no way to mark or indicate your home base without building some obvious structure on the island you settle on. I was hoping for more of a hud element that I can bring into view with the compass, unless there's something I missed?

- Mid to end game should definitely captialize on the airship aspect of the game. There was one island I saw floating high above my ships limit and noticed some dungeon structure tucked into the sides. Plenty of open space to park directly into the dungeon in a way which provides a really neat approach to the dungeons. Though I feel the higher a player goes, the harder the game should get? I'm not entirely certain on how this should work, but if the loot you get doesn't scale with your progression, we're gonna end up with a Minecraft failure where you're essentially giving the player a stack of diamonds before they can even craft a wooden pickaxe.

Is there anything I missed? I'm deeply invested in seeing where this game goes. For now, I'll leave it as a negative review since I'm concerned about progression and the mid to end game experience. Overall, I'm very excited for this title. Compared to Minecraft, this one has a specific focus in mind.

Currently, what sets Everwind apart from any other block game? The answer should be the game's [i]Unique Selling Point[/i], the airship gameplay and exploration. However, at least in the demo, all features feel seriously underbaked and underwhelming. I would not be surprised if Minecraft mods have achieved a similar level of gameplay despite the game's engine barely supporting such functionality.

Exploration is at least better than in a few other action-adventurey-RPGish games I have played. I was pleasantly surprised to find improved gear, or even weapons and armor that are above what I can make myself from various chests. It is nice to see that the game is not above rewarding the player for exploration. In addition, the verticality in dungeons is a very pleasant addition.

However, that is where the praise ends for now. Below are a myriad of smaller and larger issues that cropped up during the demo gameplay.

[h3]Combat issues:[/h3]
[list]
[*]Combat is functional, but too simplistic. You have a basic attack, a heavy attack and a block. Heavy attacks are only useful as openers or if the enemy has a lot of armor. Blocking... might work? Not sure. Beyond that you just swing until the enemy stops moving. Most of them don't have the DPS to kill you before you kill them, anyway.
[*]Different weapons do not feel particularly different at all. That said, I only saw a couple of different kinds of weapons, but they were largely similar. Why does nobody try to copy Vermintide's homework?
[*]Enemies are only threatening in large numbers, or only if you have for some reason run out of food to heal yourself with. Most enemies, including the Skeleton King are easily defeated by standing on top of something they cannot reach.
[/list]

[h3]Survival issues:[/h3]
[list]
[*]Survival effectively does not exist. You do not have needs other than keeping your health above 0. You can only lose health through falling from extreme heights, being hit by traps or through combat.
[*]Food is plentiful and its only purpose is to serve as glorified healing potions.
[*]Alchemy is pointless and not particularly fun. You have to match three ingredients with matching effects to make a basic potion that is likely not even particularly useful. You cannot see more than one out of three possible effects in the demo.
[*]Repairing items is laughably easy. Copper is the most abundant metal in the game, and all you need are a few pieces of ore to to turn into ingots, and some planks to make a repair kit that fixes anything to maximum durability.
[*]The game is severely hindered by everything being gated behind recipes you find randomly. Up to and including smelting ingots, and making anything out of said ingots. You can easily get into a situation where you find recipes for bronze or iron equipment, but can't smelt the ingots to make said items.
[*]Recipes are not shared. In multiplayer means one player may be able to smelt ingots, but another might have a recipe for the tools or weapons that utilize those ingots. Given random generation of recipes, you may wind up with heaps of duplicates but not the ones you need.
[/list]

[h3]Airship issues:[/h3]
[list]
[*]The airship building is completely arbitrary. Right now the most effective way to build your flying boat is to just make a one-dimensional flying saucer. Form and function are completely divorced from one another.
[*]Airship components are arbitrary. The balloons effectively do nothing beyond add +250 max height, limited by the level of your ship's core. You do not have to balance the lift evenly around your boat. Even without any balloons, your boat can still hover up to 15 blocks (technically 7, because sea level is 7 blocks). 
[*]I'm not sure if the generators do anything at all beyond just toggling your balloons and rotors on for as long as there is power. Do you need more than one? Who knows.
[*]Furthermore, the motors that add speed to your boat can be placed anywhere, even in places where their air currents should be completely blocked. In addition, given that in the demo the max speed is 13.5 blocks, you need two propellers to get to 13 max speed. The third motor adds only a .5 block speed increase before limited by the hard cap.
[*]Mass does not exist. Your airship can carry as much stuff on it as you can fit in boxes and whatnot. You do not need to build a base anywhere, because your flying saucer does and carries everything.
[*]Your airship seemingly can not take damage, making using different blocks entirely cosmetic. The most effective way to make your airboat, therefore, is to make a flat saucer with the ballons and motors stacked next to one another in some corner, fed by a single generator.
[*]If the airboat cannot take damage, then there likely are no flying enemies either that could threaten you and your boat, making using harder blocks pointless and the flying itself uneventful and boring.
[/list]

[h3]Technical issues:[/h3]
[list]
[*]The game freezes consistently after a few hours of gameplay.
[*]Turning up the chunk loading setting causes crippling chugging.
[*]The game lags considerably when an island is generated.
[*]Virtually no quality of life features. Cannot easily stack stuff in boxes, have to do everything manually and one by one. Same for crafting, no way to craft large amounts of items at once.
[*]No FOV settings?
[*]No rebindable keys in demo?
[/list]

Hopefully the full game will provide a far better air boat captain/crew fantasy than what the demo showcased. The systems need more depth and design. The airship should be the most developed feature and the beating heart and soul of the game. Yet, as it stands right now, it seems little more than a cute gimmick for the game to set itself apart from any other block game.

Without a road map, I can't say for certain that the game is going in the right direction. It has HUGE promise considering the mechanics and little details that already exist so far for this demo.

I'm certain the ships being provided from the start is for the demo ONLY to give players a quick cut to the airship gameplay, however if they're handed out like this in the final product, the main selling point of this game (for me and likely many others) will feel pretty shallow. I highly doubt this is the case, but if it is, then it's pretty sad.

I think it's fine if there's far and few wrecked ships for you to salvage or convert into a fully working airship, but starting from the ground up would be awesome as well. Progression in this game is going to be a major make or break point for me, and if it's as shallow as the demo experience is providing, I'm going to get really bored of this faster than I do with my Minecraft phases. So what are my personal takes/expectations? This isn't going to be fully organized, just some key points from the few hours I've played.

- A slow but meaningful journey to building your first airship.

- Combat improvements (Saw complaints about poorly telegraphed attacks and how it's basically a slapping contest for who slaps the fastest, I strongly agree with this comparison. Combat is pretty dull currently.)

- Enemy variety. If all of the enemies have to be skeletons, that's fine, but I would like to see the skeletons be something more than melee and ranged fighters. (They use mounts or other creatures for whatever evil things they do for example.) This could incentivize the use of multiple combat approaches, and maybe inspire the improved combat?

- Using the separate crafting benches feels a bit arbitrary if you are able to craft a majority of things like the different wood blocks in your characters inventory. Though I can kinda see where they're going with them since certain benches can craft specific things.

- Exploration is a bit iffy to me. I'd love to be able to claim an island as a home base that I can park my ship at when I return from exploring. The problem is that there's no way to mark or indicate your home base without building some obvious structure on the island you settle on. I was hoping for more of a hud element that I can bring into view with the compass, unless there's something I missed?

- Mid to end game should definitely captialize on the airship aspect of the game. There was one island I saw floating high above my ships limit and noticed some dungeon structure tucked into the sides. Plenty of open space to park directly into the dungeon in a way which provides a really neat approach to the dungeons. Though I feel the higher a player goes, the harder the game should get? I'm not entirely certain on how this should work, but if the loot you get doesn't scale with your progression, we're gonna end up with a Minecraft failure where you're essentially giving the player a stack of diamonds before they can even craft a wooden pickaxe.

Is there anything I missed? I'm deeply invested in seeing where this game goes. For now, I'll leave it as a negative review since I'm concerned about progression and the mid to end game experience. Overall, I'm very excited for this title. Compared to Minecraft, this one has a specific focus in mind.
